titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Economic Development and Administration, Problems of the Aging
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Economic Development and Administration, Problems of the Aging FA1549

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-10-22 05:38:01 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Economic Development and Administration, Problems of the Aging

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation's Problems of Aging program was a concerted effort to fund grants to help older citizens in the areas of 1.) housing and living arrangements and 2.) employment and retirement problems. At the height of the program, between 1956 and 1961, the Foundation made 42 grants and appropriations over $5.6 million. The grants were made to universities, local welfare and planning groups, and national voluntary and professional organizations. The goals of the initiative were to:

1.) Strengthen local-community action through programs designed to help older people help themselves, and through demonstration projects for improved planning and use of facilities, services, and funds
2.) Improve living arrangements for older individuals
3.) Develop sound factual knowledge on which to base retirement policies and practices
4.) Improve understanding of the employment problems faced by middle-aged and older workers through basic research and expansion of counseling, retraining, and placement services
5.) Strengthen teaching on problems of aging in schools of social work and other professional schools; and improve in-service training programs in public and private social-service agencies

The program started in 1956 with an appropriation of $500,000 granted to the National Social Welfare Assembly to be used by their National Committee on the Aging (NCOA) for the next five years. With this funding, the NCOA greatly expanded its research program and shared its practical findings widely throughout the United States. In December 1959, the Board of Trustees appropriated $300,000 for a series of demonstration projects in different U.S. communities with the goal of improving the organization of local programs for older people. These demonstration projects were carried out by: the Community Chest and Council of the Greater Worcester (Mass.) Area; the Community Welfare Council of the Richmond (Calif.) Area; the Denver Metropolitan Council for Community Services; the Health and Welfare Council of Metropolitan St. Louis; Marion County (Kan.) Department of Social Welfare; Minnesota State Department of Public Welfare; and the United Community Fund of San Francisco. The program began issuing terminal grants for the program in 1961, but the Ford Foundation continued to fund research into social issues for older individuals after 1967.

Stacey Widdicombe, a Program Associate within the Ford Foundation's Economic Development and Administration division, led the Problems of the Aging program. Prior to working on the Aging initiative, he was Assistant to the Foundation's Vice President Thomas H. Carroll.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at the RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files, and officers' papers were transferred to and accessioned by the RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary. This material was transferred to the RAC in 2019 and was ingested by the RAC as part of Program Strategy records, Accession 2019:012.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is arranged into two series:
Series 2: Office Files and Background Correspondence
The original order of the material was maintained.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Standard Processing by Katie Martin, September 2019.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use". If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the users responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains correspondence, meeting materials, grant approval materials, reports, and memos related to the Ford Foundation's Problems of the Aging program within the Economic Development and Administration department. The collection primarily consists of the office files of Stacey Widdicombe, a program associate who led the Problems of the Aging program. Materials within the collection relate to the 1961 White House Conference on Aging, the Senate's Special Committee on Aging, the National Committee on Aging, research into social issues of older Americans, social security issues, economic and housing issues for older individuals, and rights of older workers.

Some materials in the collection relate to other projects within the Foundation's Economic Development and Administration program, including disarmament and grants for business education in colleges and universities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, meeting notes, reports, and articles related to the Ford Foundation's program on the Problems of Aging. From the office files of Stacey Widdecombe, Ford Foundation program associate.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Subject Files S-W organized alphabetically by name of agency, demonstration project location, committee, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, discussion notes, meeting materials, memos, and reports primarily related to the Ford Foundation's program on the Problems of Aging. There are materials related to other projects within the Ford Foundation's Economic Development and Administration, including the economics of disarmament and grants for business schools.

did.unittitle: A National Foundation Expresses its Interest in the Problems of Older People, Dr. Thomas H. Carroll, Vice President of the Ford Foundation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: From title page: "A speech by Dr. Thomas H. Carroll, Vice President of the Ford Foundation, and President-Elect, The George Washington University, at a special meeting of the White House Conference on Aging on "Highways to Economic Security" at the Shoreham Hotel on Monday, 9 January 1961. Dr. Carroll has had officer responsibility for the Ford Foundation's program dealing with the problems and potentials of older people."

Notes also indicate this folder was saved for potential inclusion in the International Affairs Chronological Correspondence Files.
